lines.text:
[when asked to prepare Harold's very first alcoholic beverage]
You arouse the artist in me.
Everyman is the architect of his own fortune.
Well, crown my kittens, this is quite a moment.
It has always seemed to me that the cocktail should approach us on tip-toe, like a young girl, whose first appeal - is innocence.
What a poet!
Here's to innocence!
Bottoms up!
Over your ears!
Did you ever hear of the Trojan Horse?
Where was he running?
As you know, Mr. Smoke, you are loathed by everyone.
Wha-wha-why?
Because you are a banker.
As soon as I have a minute, I'll thank you for hours.
He who loses honor, loses everything.

We don't start people at the top, you understand. That would be too easy. We do it the American way! We give them an opportunity to work up! - from the bottom. What satisfaction! What the feeling of accomplishment you will have, when you are able to look back, from whatever rung of the ladder you're, eh, go-getiveness would have paced you on, to say, I - I did that!

You have not only ceased to go forward, you have gone backward. You have not only stopped progressing, you have stopped thinking! You not only make the same mistakes, year after year, you don't even change your apologies. You have become a bottleneck! You are the living proof of the low quality of work we demand of our employees and a bad example to the younger employees who figure that if you can get away with it, they can too and they don't have to be any better than you are! Which is zero.

[after just firing Harold]
Goodbye and good luck. And as a parting thought, I want you to know that this is hurting me much more than it is you, Harold. Much more!
Thank you, very much. Goodbye.
Don't let it get you down.
Once bitten, twice shy.
A fool and his money are soon parted.
He who lendeth money, endeth friendship.
What you need is a drink.
No, I never touch it. I never have. It runs in my family, not to. The demon rum...
I tell you what I'm going to do, since you've been so generous and all...
No. No. I tell you I have never in my whole life...
You're never too old to learn.
You can't teach an old dog, new tricks.
Every dog is entitled to one bite.
Let sleeping dogs lie.
A barking dog never bites!
He who sleepeth with dogs, rises with fleas!
Now, wait a minute. How 'bout, eh, a little wine for they stomach's sake. That's from The Good Book! He who hesitates is lost.
Live to touch liquour, shall never touch wine.
Eat, drink and be merry!
The priest and the prophet have erred through strong drink, they are swallowed up of wine, they are out of the way through strong drink; they err in vision, they stumble in judgment. Isaiah 28.
You've got me.
What kind of a drink would you suggest? Nothing too strong, of course.
A wise man keepeth his own council.
This calls for a little celebration, Mr., eh...
Diddlebock. Harold Diddlebock.
Diddle what?
Diddlebock. Bock - as in beer.
Oh, I thought you said, Diddlebuck - as in buckwheat cakes.
No, I didn't
Brother Diddlebuck, eh, back, eh, bu, eh, what's the matter with me?
Bock.

[Deciding what to fix for Harold's first drink - ever]
I was thinking of a Texas Tornado.
vestal? I mean it ought to have organ music. I mean opportunities like this come along all too rarely for a man with his heart in his work.

[Fixing Harold's first alcoholic drink]
Now, just a couple of technical questions. Would you like it frappé or flambé?
How?
Do you like ice skating or Turkish baths?
I used to skate, a little.
Frappé!
A Diddlebock isn't really a drink.
A what?
It's just a little thing I invented in Brother Diddlebock's honor.
It's more like fruit cup, really. A fruit cup with - sex appeal.
Why don't you give the gentleman a drink instead of letting him stand there with his tongue hanging out!

[Looking at himself in a mirror]
Why, I wouldn't trust a face like that to empty a spittoon!
Very clever! I guess I have to get up pretty early in the morning to catch you in bed.
It's been tried.
Oh!
When the iron is hot, strike! Obey that impulse!

When old Mrs. Chauncey called out the window, "The night was made for sleep, Mr. Diddlebock", you and your drunken friends had to holler back, "The night was made for love, Mrs. Chauncey! Or have you forgotten?"
I said that?
Said it, you sang!
I wonder if anybody saw me?
Oh, no, of course, not. You probably didn't attract any more attention than Lady Godiva in Macy's window at noon!
Excuse me, you didn't happen to notice what I did with any of that money, did you? Or, even some of it?
Oh, you were most free with it, sir. The women were at your feet, sir, if I may be so bold.
They were?
Prostrate, sir, absolutely, on his uncle. The weaker sex simply adore a generous man, sir.
My circus? Who, in heaven's name, ever gave you the idea that I had a circus?

Who ever give me the idea? You sent me out to take care of it, didn't you? Right in the middle of a party, didn't you? Just when I'm gettin' in good with this big blonde, I got to beat it out to Queens, just in time for an elephant to squirt a bucket of ice water in my kisser and for one of them cats to, well never mind that.
I was even in love with the same girl all my life; except, in different bodies.
Same with me. I gotta have change all the time. So long, Suzie. Hello, Nellie! Hail - and farewell!
You know something else? He may have been right to fire me. I'm just an old has-been.
What are you talkin' about? If ever I seen a live wire, a good-time Charlie with the rubber off his roller and a whistle for the dames.
Where there's a problem, there must be a solution. Where there's a mind, there must be thought. You follow me?
Now, where do you get money?
Eh, Wall Street?
Correct. And where in Wall Street?
A bank?
Correct, again. And how do you get that money out of that bank?
A hold-up?

[Repeated line]
I hate bankers!
There's nothing that succeeds...
Like success!
No! Like thought! With thought you can penetrate...
Granite walls!
Right! - All we need, then, is a thought!
Drop that gun!
Here, have a drink.
I don't want to be popular. I don't like nobody and nobody likes me. If it's all right with them, it's all right with me.
Here, have a drink.
Certainly. That's the one thing I do like.
Oh, I thought you were in trouble.
Far from it! Do I look as if I were in trouble? Now, you didn't happen to see any bankers downstairs, on your way up here, did you?
No, I didn't Mr. Diddlebock. Only a colored man.
What was he doing?
Mopping the floor.
Don't talk nonsense, Mr. Diddlebock. Don't be depressed. The day is always darkest...
I know, just before the cyclone.
Did anyone see any bankers around here?
Ringling Brothers, Barnum & Bailey Circus bought your circus.
Ringling Brothers, Barnum & Bailey Circus? You mean for money?
Well, he certainly didn't buy it for peanuts.
Why didn't you resist me, Miss Otis?
Because, you were irresistible, Mr. Diddlebock.
Piffle! Bunk! Sentimental drib drab.

[Last lines]
That must be what I was doing all day Wednesday!
